claim: Twins are always born during the same year.

supporting.text: Twins are typically born within minutes or hours of each other, ensuring they share the same birth year.

attacks.text: Twins are typically born within minutes or hours of each other, ensuring they share the same birth year.
In rare cases, twins can be born on either side of midnight on New Year's Eve, resulting in different birth years.
The probability of twins being born across different years is extremely low, making the original argument statistically valid in almost all cases.
Twins born via cesarean section are sometimes scheduled for delivery on different days for medical reasons, potentially spanning different years.
Scheduled cesarean deliveries across year boundaries are exceptionally rare and usually avoided when possible.

supporting.text: Medical records and birth certificates universally document twins as being born on the same date or within the same 24-hour period, guaranteeing the same year.

attacks.text: Medical records and birth certificates universally document twins as being born on the same date or within the same 24-hour period, guaranteeing the same year.
In rare cases, twins can be born on either side of midnight, resulting in different birth dates and potentially different years (e.g., New Year's Eve and New Year's Day).
Such cases are extremely rare and statistically negligible, making the original argument practically valid for nearly all twins.
Even in rare cases, birth certificates may still record the same date due to administrative conventions or timezone differences.

supporting.text: The biological process of twin gestation results in simultaneous or near-simultaneous delivery, preventing cross-year births.

attacks.text: The biological process of twin gestation results in simultaneous or near-simultaneous delivery, preventing cross-year births.
Twins born near midnight on New Year's Eve can technically be born in different years due to time zone differences or delayed delivery of the second twin.
Time zone differences are administrative constructs and do not change the biological simultaneity of twin births.
In extremely rare cases, delayed interval delivery (days or weeks apart) has been documented for twins, potentially crossing calendar years.
Delayed interval deliveries exceeding 24 hours occur in less than 0.1% of twin pregnancies and are medically managed to avoid year-crossing.

supporting.text: No documented cases exist of twins born in different years under normal circumstances, as labor for twins occurs in a single continuous event.

attacks.text: No documented cases exist of twins born in different years under normal circumstances, as labor for twins occurs in a single continuous event.
In rare cases like New Year's Eve births, twins can be born in different years due to the timing of labor spanning midnight.
Such New Year's Eve cases are statistically negligible and don't invalidate the general rule about twin births.
Time zone differences during international travel could theoretically result in twins being born in different years.
No verified cases exist of twins being born in different years due to time zone changes during labor.

supporting.text: Statistically, the likelihood of twins being born in different years is negligible due to the short interval between their births.

attacks.text: Statistically, the likelihood of twins being born in different years is negligible due to the short interval between their births.
Twins born near midnight on New Year's Eve can be born in different years despite the short interval.
The occurrence of twins born in different years is statistically rare and does not significantly impact the general claim.
Medical interventions or complications can extend the interval between twin births, increasing the chance of different birth years.
Even with extended intervals, the vast majority of twin births occur within minutes or hours, making different birth years highly unlikely.
